thread.title: College Sports: Baylor fires strength coach Brandon Washington after arrest on prostitution charge | SportsDay
thread.title_full: College Sports: Baylor fires strength coach Brandon Washington after arrest on prostitution charge | SportsDay

author: Adam Grosbard
title: College Sports: Baylor fires strength coach Brandon Washington after arrest on prostitution charge | SportsDay
text:
This story is about Baylor Bears Published Baylor fires strength coach Brandon Washington after arrest on prostitution charge This Story is About... Comment on This Story Staff Photographer McLane Stadium on the campus of Baylor University in Waco, Texas Thursday May 26, 2016. On May 26 the Baylor University Board of Regents announced after a sexual assault investigation that university president Ken Starr will transition to the role of Chancellor and remains professor at Baylor University Law School and head football coach Art Briles will be suspended with intent to terminate. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) By Adam Grosbard , Staff Writer Contact Adam Grosbard on Twitter: @AdamGrosbard 
Baylor strength coach Brandon Washington was arrested early Saturday morning as part of a prostitution sting, according to a report from The Waco Tribune . 
Shortly after the news broke, Baylor released a statement announcing it had terminated Washington following the arrest. 
"After a full criminal background check was completed and cleared, Brandon Washington was recently hired as an assistant in the Football Strength and Conditioning area," the statement read. "Baylor was notified on February 4 of Brandon Washington's arrest and terminated his employment immediately that day." 
"When we arrived at Baylor we made a commitment to character and integrity in our program. Brandon's actions are completely unacceptable," head coach Matt Rhule added. "We will not tolerate conduct that is contradictory to these values." 
Washington, 33, was arrested at a local hotel on a solicitation of prostitution charge, McLennan County Sheriff Parnell McNamara confirmed to The Tribune . If convicted for the Class B misdemeanor, Washington faces a maximum sentence of 180 days in jail and/or a fine of no more than $2,000. 
Washington, who was released on a $1,000 bond from McLennan County Jail on Saturday, was a member of the strength training staff at Temple last season and followed former Temple head coach Rhule to Baylor this winter.
